question: How do small particles form sedimentary rocks like shale and sandstone?

content.source_1: Sedimentary rocks commonly form when loose sediments accumulate in layers and are buried; over time, compaction and cementation lithify the sediments into rock.
content.source_2: Shale (from clay- and silt-sized particles) and sandstone (from sand-sized grains) are classic clastic sedimentary rocks.
content.source_3: Lithification involves compaction that squeezes out pore water and cementation that precipitates minerals (e.g., calcite or silica) to bind grains together.
content.source_4: Igneous rocks form by the cooling and crystallization of magma or lava; volcanic eruptions can deposit ash that later becomes volcanic tuff, a layered rock of consolidated volcanic particles.
content.source_5: Explosive volcanism produces sand-sized fragments and glass shards (tephra); hot, thick deposits can weld or solidify into coherent rock with little transport.
content.source_6: Quartz, abundant in many sands and sandstones, crystallizes from silica-rich magmas; volcanic ash can alter to clay minerals that are the main constituents of shale.
